title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Mr. Paterson was agrandson of Robert Paterson, "Old Mortality," and brother of the Rev.Walter Paterson, minister of Kirkurd, author of the _Legend of Iona_--apoem written in imitation of the style of Scott, and in which herecognises his obligations to Sir Walter in the following terms:--"Fromhim I derived courage to persevere in an undertaking on which I hadoften reflected with terror and distrust."--_Legend_, notes, p.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The other, longer andmore circuitous, cuts straight over the rough moorlands to the littlevillage of Newlands, then over much wild country to Kirkurd, and thehigh hills which hem in the hamlet of Broughton, whence it is but fivemiles to the house of Dawyck.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Sir David Scott of Kirkurd and Buccleuch likewise obtained great gifts of landfor his clan's service and his own, at the battle of Arkinholme, and began thatcourse of greatness which raised his family to the ducal dignity.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: 1 " Sir Walter Scott, of Kirkurd, the male ancestor of theBuccleuch family, on 22d February, 1458-9, got a charter oflands in the barony of Crawfordjohn, pro eo quod intersuitconftictu de Arkinholme, in occisione, el capttore rebelliumquondam Archib.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Sir Walter Scott of Kirkurd and Buccleuchlikewise obtained great gifts of land for his clan'sservice and his own, at the battle of Arkinholme,and began that course of greatness which raisedhis family to the ducal dignity.1Such, my dear child, is the course of the world,in which the downfaU of one great man or familyis the means of advancing others; as a falling treethrows its seed upon the ground, and causes youngplants to arise in its room.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Sir Walter Scott of Kirkurd and Buccleuchlikewise obtained great gifts of land for his clan'sservice and lus own, at the battle of Arkinholme,and began tliat course of greatness wliich raisedhis family to the ducal dignity.1Such, my dear child, is the course of the world,in which the downfall of one great man or familyis the means of advancing others: as a falling treethrows its seed upon the ground, and causes youngplants to arise in its room.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Sir David Scott of Kirkurd and Buccleuch obtained also great gifts of land for his clan's service andhis own, at the battle of Arkinholme, and beganthat course of greatness which raised his family to theducal dignity.
